If you had to choose something, even something small, that this struggle has given the world in terms of knowledge about how to resolve differences or knowledges about how to negotiate these constraints that people have put on each other in this growth of human society, what has your experience as an Australian, the experience that led up to this apology offered to other people who are looking around at the struggles over indigenous rights and race and ethnicity in their own countries?
I would just have to say - I mean, it's been a real eye-opener for me as an aboriginal person.
Aboriginal people have grown to be extremely cynical about the words of government, about promises that are made.

The fact that there has been this consultation - and it was an unprecedented level of consultation - we, the members of the stolen generation, people who were literally removed, were asked, what would it personally mean to you if we apologized?
The government was at pains to say we asked the people that this apology matters to most.
I mean, the words of the prime minister that you played were part of it.
He also apologized very specifically for the removal of aboriginal kids, for breaking up families, for the indignity and degradation inflicted on a proud people.
That acknowledgement is just absolutely massively powerful for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

It says you acknowledge our experiences, where previously, you know, I know - older members of our community who are in their 60s and 70s have said to me I have been through my entire life looking into the eyes of white Australians, and I know that they think I'm a liar.
Now to have people being validated, after, you know, six or seven decades of that kind of denial is exceptionally powerful.
On that note, Kirstie, thank you for your time.
My pleasure.
Kirstie Parker is the managing editor of The Koori Mail, a newspaper that covers Australia's national indigenous issues, and she joined me from Lismore in New South Wales, Australia.
